overview.short: Brevibacterium species are Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, aerobic coryneform rods commonly associated with human skin and dairy environments.
overview.clinical_context: Usually considered skin commensals but can cause opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised hosts or prosthetic-associated infections.

field_notes.Pigment: Orange to reddish pigmentation is common and intensifies with incubation.
field_notes.NaCl Tolerance: Growth in high salt supports differentiation from many other coryneform bacteria.
field_notes.Gelatin Hydrolysis: Frequently positive and useful for differentiation.

key_differentiators.notes: Catalase positivity separates Brevibacterium from many anaerobic Gram-positive rods.
High salt tolerance supports Brevibacterium identification.

common_confusions.reason: Shared coryneform morphology and catalase positivity.
Overlapping skin-associated habitat and Gram-positive rods.

when_to_question_identification: Strict anaerobic growth argues against Brevibacterium.
Absence of pigmentation should prompt reconsideration.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports differentiation from similar coryneform bacteria.
Commercial identification system suitable for coryneform organisms.
Gold standard for accurate species-level identification.
